metadata.title: Determinants in the adoption of a non-labor-substitution technology: mechanical ventilation in West Virginia coal mines, 1898-1907

relevance.relevance: The study examines the adoption of mechanical ventilation, a non-labor-substitution technology, in West Virginia coal mines, providing insights into technology adoption decisions and their determinants.

design.sample_characteristics: Mines in West Virginia employing at least ten miners, surveyed between 1898 and 1907.

key_themes: Resistance to new technology due to costs
text_fragments: 'In mines where there is fire damp the fan has a decided advantage over the furnace (…) The current produced by a fan is more regular than can be produced by a furnace' (WVDM 1889, p. 5).

'(…) if the first cost of installing a fan could be done as cheaply as a great many of the makeshift furnaces, I am satisfied there would not be a mine in the country without a fan' (WVDM 1905, p. 241).
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the adoption of mechanical ventilation as a response to safety concerns in coal mines, highlighting the role of costs and benefits in technology adoption decisions.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Period of economic expansion in the West Virginia coal basin, with increasing coal production and mechanization.
historical_context.institutional_context: Lack of strict safety regulations and legal requirements for ventilation methods in West Virginia coal mines during the study period.

outcomes.main_findings: The adoption of mechanical ventilation was influenced by factors such as the presence of firedamp, previous explosions, mine size, mechanization level, and productivity.
outcomes.conclusions: Mechanical ventilation was adopted relatively quickly in response to safety concerns, despite the persistence of older technologies due to cost considerations.
